activity-description.narrative: Refreshment Training: Continuing Judicial Education (CJE) 3rd Round
The project will work together with the Supreme Court of Indonesia, where its secretariat is located in Jakarta, Indonesia. The project's office is located at the 12th floor of the Secretariat.

description.narrative:
2.1. (1) Increased capacity of SC Training Centre on curriculum development based on a training needs assessment; delivery of training programmes for candidate registrars and bailiffs, continuing judicial education, leadership training for senior judges, and certification programmes; evaluation of training by using the Kirkpatrick's four levels of evaluation model; and development of sustainable e-learning model by taking stock on available approach from other institutions 2.1. (2) Full integration of new training and education system developed into the standard curriculum proposed by the Supreme Court's Training Centre Annual Output Indicator Year 1. Increased intensity and quality of ToT program Year 2. Increased intensity and quality of ToT program Year 3. Increased intensity and quality of ToT program. Mechanism to ensure high quality TOT is proposed to Pusdiklat Year 4. Road Map and work plan to increase Pusdiklat capacity and Standard Curriculum is developed Year 5. Mechanism/relevant internal policy and tools to accelerate Supreme Court Training Centre high quality training is implemented and functioning
2.2 Certification programmes developed upon discussion and consultation with the Supreme Court of Indonesia. (The programmes shall consist of full cycle of certification program, from need assessment, required or relevant trainings, the certification itself, and post-certification monitoring mechanism)
Annual Output Indicator Year 1. Improved certification training curriculum Year 2. Certification training program and its training quality assurance mechanism is implemented and proposed to Pusdiklat Year 3. Certification training program and its training quality assurance mechanism is implemented and proposed to Pusdiklat Year 4. Certification training program and its training quality assurance mechanism is consistently implemented by Pusdiklat Year 5. Certification training program and its training quality assurance mechanism is consistently implemented

comment.narrative:
2.1). Last TNA conducted with the Faculty of Psychology, University of Indonesia in 2010 (2010: 225) MoV: Data Sources: 2015, SUSTAIN Output 2 Rapid Assessment Report; Collection Method: Desk review
2.2) .1,296 targeted judges and/or court staff received CJE, certification or leadership training in 2014, as follows: - Continuous Judicial Education/CJE: 453 judges (2014:254); - Certification Programmes (2014:254); Environmental Certification (82 judges), Juvenile Justice Certification (245 judges), Fishery Certification (40 judges), Mediation Certification (255 judges); - Leadership Programmes (2014:260): Training Programme for Head of District Court (93 judges), Training Programme for Registrars (170 registrars); Training on Management of Training (MOT) for the Court’s training centre unit heads, senior trainers, researchers (93 persons); Training Officers Course/(TOC (170 persons); Training Facilitators Course/TFC (98 persons) MoV: Data Source: 2014 Annual Report of Supreme Court; Collection Method: Desk review
2.3). Training evaluations not undertaken, nor do they feed into performance reviews. According to the SC Annual Report, the Training Centres plans to undertake a six monthly post training evaluation for former education and training participants and an annual post training evaluation for former management and leadership training participants (2010:258).
2.4). Even though the State Administration Institute (Lembaga Administrasi Negara/LAN) and PT TUV consider the capacity of the Training Centre to be high (in 2012, LAN awarded the Centre its highest accreditation of A [valid for five years]; whilst PT TUV has certified the Centre provides training and education in line with international standards), the absence of TNA and post-training evaluation, demonstrate the Centre’s capacity can be further strengthened. MoV: Data Source: Head of LAN Decree No 2811/K.I/PDP.10.4/2012, dated 14 December 2012(2012:200); and PT TUV Nord-Indonesia Cer

2.1. (1) Training of Trainers for four chambers 2.1. (2) Continuation of Network refinement at Balitbang Diklat Kumdil (MA’s Training Center); Develop, implement and evaluate e-learning tools for Continuing Judicial Education & Candidate Judges Training for Code of Conduct training 2.1. (3) E-Monitoring and Evaluation, and Monev Module Development for Certification and supporting programmes 2.1. (4) Policy Advocacy in Training Budgeting
2.2. (1) Training on Corruption Prevention and Public Outreach 2.2. (2) Integrated Training on Fishery Crimes in Coastal Area 2.2. (3) Integrated Training on Civil Cases of Environment Law 2.2. (4) Integrated Juvenile Certification Training 2.2. (5) FGD High Level for Validation of Fishery Handbook 2.2. (6) Printing Fishery handbook 2.2. (7) Launching Fishery Handbook in Coastal area 2.2. (8) Communication strategy
2.3. (1) Monitoring and Evaluation and Mentoring of CRBT Participants 2.3. (2) FGD on CRBT Handbook Development, Editing Process, Layouting 2.3. (3) Printing of CRBT Handbook
2.4. (1 )FGD Module development for Tax Court Refreshment Training 2.4. (2) Refreshment Training for Tax Court Judges and Registrars and its module development
2.5. (1) FGD on Selected Topics of Supreme Court Regulation on Administrative 2.5. (2) Monitoring and Evaluation and Mentoring for Second round of CJE training (level 3&4 Kirkpatricks Learning Model)
2.6. (1) FGD on Development Leadership Training module in Ciawi Bogor 2.6. (2) Leadership training for four chamber of judiciaries from 15 pilot court 2.6. (3) Monitoring and Evaluations and Mentoring for Crash Program Judges 2.6. (4) Leadership training extended class

2.1. (1) In January 2018, the project held a TOT with 50 participants from all four chambers of judiciary to be certified as trainers. These trainers further add to the list of trainers for candidate judges. 2.1. (2) The project facilitated the refinement of SISDIKLAT application by adding more features such as electronic monitoring and evaluation of training, and integration with HR application (SIKEP) and supervision application (SIWAS). The refinement process was not able to be completed on time by end of 2018, and will be continued in 2019. 2.1. (3) The e-monitoring and evaluation application was still in development by the end of 2018. This development will continue in 2019. 2.1. (4) The project no longer pursue this objective due to low prioritization by the Supreme Court.
2.2. (1) The project held 2 integrated training targeting 99 personnel (30% women) to prevent corruption within the government of Riau Province and Malang, Tulungagung, and Blitar Districts. 2.2. (2) The project held 1 integrated training in Semarang targeting 36 beneficiaries (11% women) for handling IUUF crimes on the northern Java coast areas. 2.2. (3) The project held 1 integrated training targeting 37 beneficiaries (32% women) on the issue of civil environmental cases, conducted in Jayapura 2.2. (4) The project held 1 integrated training targeting 35 beneficiaries (63% women) in handling juveniles on criminal cases in Ambon. This training was also followed up with a monitoring visit in December 2018 2.2. (5) The project held 2 FGDs high level to validate and finalize the handbook in coastal area. By the end of 2018, the draft of the handbook was finished, but still requires approval from leaders of ministry/agencies involved. 2.2. (6) This objective was not completed since the handbook was not finished by the end of 2018. 2.2. (7) This objective was not completed since the handbook was not finished by the end of 2018. 2.2. (8) The project held a public discussion on matters of corruption within the judiciary at Brawijaya University in Malang. The discussion invited law students from Brawijaya University.
2.3. (1) The project and the CRBT trainers visited former trainees at courts across 11 areas to monitor the impact of the CRBT training held in 2017. The training was found to have significant positive impact, specifically to the registrar. 2.3. (2) The project held 2 FGDs to discuss the handbook for CRBT, but was not able to finish by the end of 2018, due to several regulations released later on which should be incorporated to the handbook. 2.3. (3) This objective was not completed since the handbook was not finished by the end of 2018
2.4. The activities to these objectives were not able to be implemented due to the delay in the process of Tax Court judge selection. The project will still pursue these objectives in 2018.
2.5. (1) The project held an FGD to Develop of Supreme Court Regulation on Administrative Legal Action (Upaya Administratif). The draft was enacted at the end of 2018. 2.5. (2) The project visited 10 Administrative Courts to gather evidence of their improvement of skills and knowledge (Semarang, Makassar, Pekanbaru, Medan, Jakarta, Surabaya, Manado, Batam, Palembang, Banjarmasin). From this activity it was gathered that the some curriculum needs to be updated and sessions inviting external relevant parties was the best session.
2.6. (1) Technical Leadership Training module was developed. 2.6. (2) SUSTAIN facilitated a training to improve ability of 36 Chief of Courts (11% women) from 3 court environments (general, religious, and military). Administrative court was not included as they already have their own leadership training in 2017. 2.6. (3) This activity was not able to be held in 2018. The project will pursue this activity in 2019. 2.6. (4) In addition to the training for Chief of Courts, SUSTAIN also facilitated the same training in Surabaya for 40 Vice Chief of Courts (15% women).

2.1. (1) Internalization of electronic Training Monitoring and Evaluation application
2.2. (1) Finalization, Printing and Launching of Fishery handbook 2.2. (2) Monitoring and Evaluation of Juvenile Certification Programme in Kupang
2.3. (1) CRBT programme in Makassar 2.3. (2) Finalization, printing and launching CRBT Handbook
2.4. (1) Basic Training for Tax Court Judges
2.5. (1) Finalisation of the Compilation Book on Selected French Administration Court Decision. 2.5. (2) FGDs on selected Supreme Court Regulation on Administrative Court
2.6. (1) FGD Development Sisdiklat Policy 2.6. (2) Monitoring and Evaluation of the leadership training programme and its action plan 2.6. (3) Monitoring, Evaluations and Mentoring for Crash Program Judges in Aceh

2.1. (1) The electronic Training Monitoring and Evaluation application was finalized, complete with training and user manual. the project has also trained BALITBANG DIKLAT KUMDIL staff to utilize the new application
2.2. (1) Due to the problem in the political buy-in process of the handbook, the finalized handbook was not endorsed by leaders of all parties involved in the drafting process. Therefore, the project only able to finalize the script, and did not continue to pursue this objective. 2.2. (2) This M&E activity was able to be held in 4 areas around Kupang. The team found that law enforcement is enthusiastic in working together but infrastructure problem hampered regular communication between them.
2.3. (1) The training ran without any problem in Makassar. 2.3. (2) The CRBT handbook was finalized, printed, and disseminated to 5 areas before handovered to the chief of Supreme Court during closing ceremony of SUSTAIN project.
2.4. (1) The training ran without any problem for 14 elected new Tax Court judges in March 2019.
2.5. (1) The compilation book was finalized with endorsement from Supreme Court justices, and handovered during closing ceremony of SUSTAIN project 2.5. (2) The project is able to draft a regulation to guide judges in cases about Civil Wrongs by the Government
2.6. (1) This result was achieved, along with achievement in 2.1. (1). 2.6. (2) The M&E activity ran without any problem to court leaders in 13 areas and found that the training was very useful for the judges, specifically the public communication skill. 2.6. (3) This M&E activity ran without any problem to courts in 11 areas and found that the training does not improve their ability and a new strategy need to be drafted to increase these judges' capacity.
